thread.title: Meet the man behind the 'white guy blinking' meme | Technology
thread.title_full: Meet the man behind the 'white guy blinking' meme | Technology | The Guardian

author: Elena Cresci
title: Meet the man behind the 'white guy blinking' meme | Technology
text:
How does it feel when your face is plastered all over the internet?
Ask Drew Scanlon â€“ he knows all about it. Heâ€™s the face of a new meme you may have seen in the past few weeks.
iniroğŸ” (@eskbl) me: ill take a biology class, im smart enough for this just watch me
teacher: cells
me: pic.twitter.com/fHJJsPLioO 
February 5, 2017 His reaction face, interpreted usually as a look of incredulity, has been incredibly popular on Twitter this month. Itâ€™s been used from everything, from talking about money issues:
jaboukie young-white (@jaboukie) me: i want toâ€“
my bank account: pic.twitter.com/cmTq5mWqt2 
February 15, 2017 To poking fun at Android users:
papi ryanğŸŒŠ (@ruthlessryan_) iPhone User: Android snapchat quality is trash compared to iPhone

Android User: ...
pic.twitter.com/xSEY28Arvc 
February 21, 2017 And being mashed up with other memes:
Jen Lewis (@thisjenlewis) When you're in a fight and they make a good point pic.twitter.com/Lt7QdSrQi5 
February 21, 2017 Yet Scanlonâ€™s no stranger to seeing his face on the internet. As a video producer at Giant Bomb , a popular gaming website, he features in at least five hours of videos a week for the site, as well as on its podcast.
â€œPeople have passed around gifs of us for as long as Iâ€™ve worked at Giant Bomb,â€ he told the Guardian. 
But this is the first time heâ€™s been turned into a widespread, pretty much mainstream, meme. 
â€œItâ€™s certainly a first for me,â€ he said. 
Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
The gif itself is taken from an episode of a Giant Bomb show called Unprofessional Fridays, which was filmed back in 2013 . Scanlon and his colleagues were watching their editor, Jeff Gerstmann, play a game called Starbound. The moment comes just as Gerstmann says: â€œIâ€™ve been doing some farming with my hoe here ... â€
Scanlon doesnâ€™t remember filming this particular video â€“ it was more than three years ago after all â€“ but itâ€™s part and parcel of what the website does. â€œI think a lot of our effort in these videos is spent on getting each other to laugh, to provide things for other people to react to or riff off.
â€œMy reaction was, I think, part of that.â€
Drew Scanlon (@drewscanlon) I do public appearances, birthday parties, and bar mitzvahs. Contact my agent for day rates. https://t.co/1UNbG7QQwt 
February 17, 2017 According to Know Your Meme , the first known use of the gif was on a NeoGaf thread in 2015. But this month it sped into the 2017 meme calendar after a viral tweet about a biology class. The gif was eventually dubbed the â€œwhite guy blinkingâ€ meme and generally used as the punchline to a funny and relatable tweet.
Fans were diligent in letting Scanlon know about this new pocket of internet fame. 
â€œI first got messaged about that biology tweet â€“ which is still my favourite â€“ a few weeks ago. Since then, pretty much it has been non-stop.
â€œA lot of people have said that itâ€™s â€˜relatableâ€™ which is a bit weird because of course I am, Iâ€™m human!â€
He also got a weird insight into the Twitter accounts which rip off popular tweets as their own. He said: â€œI saw that biology tweet so many times, on different accounts.â€
a girls thoughts (@FemaIeIdeas) me: ill take a biology class, im smart enough for this just watch me
teacher: cells
me: pic.twitter.com/Jn98ivHi2u 
February 7, 2017 As weird as internet fame can be, Scanlon is relaxed about the whole thing. 
He said: â€œI like what memes can do for people. Theyâ€™re such fun, throwaway things I see. These memes have been generally positive.

â€œItâ€™s a little scary because thereâ€™s always the danger someone could change it to something different.
â€œItâ€™s not like Iâ€™ve a say in what the internet does with a gif of my face. But Iâ€™m pleased to see people are enjoying it.â€
